title: OSC orders former Bay Street lawyer Mitch Finkelstein to pay $575,000 for role in insider trading scheme
text:
Search for: OSC orders former Bay Street lawyer Mitch Finkelstein to pay $575,000 for role in insider trading scheme Topnews breaking , FP Street , Legal Post , Mitch Finkelstein , Ontario Securities Commission , Securities law Expert 
The Ontario Securities Commission has ordered former Bay Street lawyer Mitch Finkelstein to pay $575,000 in sanctions and costs for his role in an insider trading ring. 
Canada’s largest capital markets regulator Tuesday released the penalties and costs it has assessed against Finkelstein and other players implicated in the insider trading scheme. 
“Finkelstein was the instigator of significant consequences to market integrity and must bear responsibility for the chain of events which took place as a result of his breach of confidence,” write OSC commissioners Alan Lenczner and Anne Marie Ryan in the 17-page ruling. 
Finkelstein, once a rising star at blue-chip law firm Davies Ward Phillips and Vineberg LLP, was found to have passed inside stock tips to a university buddy, Paul Azeff, who was at the time an adviser at CIBC. Azeff and others then traded on the information, which had not been disclosed to the public. Three other individuals, Korin Bobrow, Howard Jeffrey Miller and Francis Cheng, were found to have used the information in violation of Ontario securities laws. 
Hearings in the case took place last year. The OSC ruled against the men in March. A sanctions hearing took place in May and the results were released Tuesday. 
Finkelstein must pay sanctions of $450,000 and costs of $125,000. He is banned from the province’s securities business for 10 years. 
Azeff must pay $750,000 in penalties, $175,000 in costs, and disgorge profits of $$49,996. He’s been kicked out of the province’s securities business for 10 years. 
Bobrow faces a $300,000 penalty, $125,000 in costs, an order to disgorge $10,217 in profits, and a 10-year ban from the securities industry. 
Miller must pay a penalty of $450,000, costs of $50,000, disgorge just $24,485 in profit. He is banned from the securities business for 10 years. Cheng faces a $200,000 penalty, a $25,000 cost order, and is banned from the industry for 10 years. 
In total, the OSC has issued penalties and costs of $2,859,698, made up of $2,150,000 in administrative monetary penalties, along with $625,000 in costs, and disgorgement orders of $84,698.
